moves.1. c4 e5: The defining moves of the English opening.
moves.2. g3 Nf6 3. Bg2 Nc6: The fianchetto set-up gives me an immediate target. I'll get solid in the center and start a king-side attack.
moves.4. Nc3 Bc5 5. a3 d6 6. b4 Bb6 7. e3 Be6: White is too active with the same piece, and taking the bishop is good enough for Black.
moves.8... O-O 9. Ne2 e4: e4! Strong pressure here and should not have been allowed.
moves.10. Nec3 Ne5 11. O-O Nxd5 12. Nxd5 Bg4: The e4 pawn will be a very active square and shows the danger in this set-up, and how weak the light squares around the king really are.
White risked a lot for a chance at a quick checkmate. Black is positioned for attack and defense.
moves.17... f6 18. Nf4 g5 19. Nd5: Looking at the weak f pawn.
moves.19... Ne5: Ne5! A block and clearing the key f3 square.
moves.22... Qh3+: White resigned. The quick loss by White here centered around the weak h3 and f3 squares, as it often does, even though the light-squared bishop was present. Other moves like Kg1, instead of cxb6, last longer, but the attack goes through the f and h files no matter what.
